Or if they see the TathÄgata's various transformations in subduing sentient beings, or his admonitory spiritual transformations, or his praiseworthy spiritual transformations;

Having seen this, they always give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment with great compassion for sentient beings, diligently seek good dharmas with great vigor, do not forget the mind of omniscience, and with corresponding practices purify the initial mind. It is like a great maá¹‡i jewel produced from a mine, which a skilled jeweler receives in his palm and skillfully refines, further polishing it;

Because that bodhisattva, first using the wholesome roots of past lives and the present hearing of the good Dharma, grinds and polishes the jewel of the mind of omniscience, until this jewel removes all false dharmas from the mind, free from faults, loved by the buddhas of the ten directions and three times, and that bodhisattva can then say that he has attained the pure seal samÄdhi gate.

First, the jewel nature of ordinary beings;
second, the jewel nature of those who follow faith;

Having transcended these nine precious natures, the tenth is called the precious nature of the firm and profound mind empowered by all buddhas, with great compassion.
When a bodhisattva thus polishes and refines the precious mind of omniscience, it surpasses all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and can illuminate the seeds in the continuum of all beings.
SÄgaramati!
Moreover, a true great maá¹‡i jewel can accommodate polishing, is able to withstand crushing and piercing without being destroyed.
That maá¹‡i jewel can be skillfully used in the world to perform meritorious deeds for beings.
Bodhisattvas who have long planted various roots of goodness are also like this.
The precious jewel of the mind set on omniscience can be polished, can withstand pressure, and cannot be pierced.
This jewel is truly free from faults, and the precious jewel of the mind set on omniscience can bring great benefit to all sentient beings.
Furthermore, SÄgaramati!
How does one skillfully polish the precious jewel of the mind set on omniscience?
It means first fully cultivating the three precepts and purifying the ten wholesome actions, because with a compassionate mind one observes all sentient beings with a pure mind;
because with a mind of compassion one goes to assist in whatever activities sentient beings are doing;
because with a mind of joy one accomplishes all the wholesome dharmas of sentient beings;
because with a mind of equanimity one does not harm any sentient being.

Because they are without flattery and deception, their minds are upright. Because they are without laziness and indolence, they deeply engage in beneficial matters with a sincere mind. Because their minds are free, they are able to give rise to all wholesome roots. Because they attain right mindfulness and right knowledge and skillfully subdue their minds, their minds are tranquil. Because they are always of few desires, they are able to cultivate the virtues of ascetic practices. Because they are able to nourish themselves well and be content, they do not cut off the holy lineage.
Because they do not give rise to contempt and arrogance towards teachers, venerable ones, and sages, they are able to be humble and always give rise to reverence.

Because their minds are stable, they are able to be free from self-conceit and conceit. Because they are without turbidity and confusion, they have no impure mind. Because they do not rely on themselves, they are able to know their own practice. Because they do not disparage others, they are able to protect sentient beings. Because they are free from conceit, they are able to draw near to the true Dharma and follow the Dharma medicine that is given.

Because they are able to comprehend various meanings, they are seekers of the Dharma. Because they gradually increase and expand the various teachings, starting with the shallow and progressing to the profound, they are able to fully possess the desire for the Dharma.
Because of cultivating the practice of being free from disputes, one always attains the joy of the Dharma.

Because of being far removed from non-dharma, one is able to diligently seek the true Dharma. Because of always being ashamed and abashed in the Three Jewels, one is able to not cut off pure faith. Because of believing in the retribution of karma, one is able to contemplate in accordance with principle all wholesome dharmas. Because of cultivating the correct practice, one is able to be hidden and tranquil in the path of deportment.

Because the mind is not lofty, one is always gentle. Because of diligently practicing Å›amatha, one is able to be free from agitation. Because of the good establishment of wisdom, one is without blame and without praise. Because of being calm and unmoving, the mind is like the king of mountains.

Because of being able to be free from the various obstacles of high and low, the mind is like the earth. Because the inner mind is pure, the mind is like water. Because of being without different thoughts, the mind is like fire. Because of being without attachment, the mind is like wind. Because of being wonderfully without defilements, the mind is like space.

Because of diligently seeking to leave the home-life, one is able to cause the Buddha-eye to never be lost. Because the body is able to be free, one delights in cultivating the practice of tranquility. Because the mind is able to be free, one always cultivates the practice of the true Dharma.
Because one does not steal due to dust-like objects in one's conduct, one speaks true words;
Because one's vows are clear and bright, one is able to practice as one speaks.

Because one is not crushed by afflictions, one's mind is always pure; because one is ultimately indestructible, one is able to cultivate pure precepts; because one is fearful even of minor offenses, one is able to keep the precepts without defect or destruction; because one does not seek rebirth in the heavens, one does not break the precepts; because one practices purely and purely, the precepts are untainted; because one always associates with good spiritual friends, one is able to illuminate the great path to enlightenment.

Because the eyes are pure, one attains unobstructed light; because the ears are pure, one attains unobstructed sounds; because the nose is pure, one attains unobstructed fragrances; because the tongue is pure, one attains unobstructed flavors; because the body is pure, one attains unobstructed tactile objects; because the mind is pure, one attains unobstructed dharmas.
Furthermore, SÄgaramati Bodhisattva!

If one wishes to be free from the fetters of greed, one should always cultivate the contemplation of impurity. If one wishes to be free from the fetters of anger, one should cultivate the contemplation of loving-kindness. If one wishes to be free from the fetters of delusion, one should cultivate the contemplation of dependent origination. If one wishes to eliminate the five hindrances, one should contemplate the five faculties well. If one wishes to uproot the various obstacles, one should purify the five powers. If one wishes to remove the presently arising afflictions, one should always be pure in the path of liberation;

By cultivating right practice, one can be free from the fears of greed, anger, delusion, pride, etc. Because of the absence of a stingy mind, one can practice the giving of Dharma. Because of the absence of miserliness, one can practice the giving of material things. Because the mind of great enlightenment is always firm, one does not delight in the teachings of other vehicles. Because the inner mind is tranquil, one can conceal the various faculties. Because the external objects are tranquil, one can contemplate the various faults well. Because one is always afraid in the cycle of birth and death, one does not commit any offenses. Because the mind is free from laziness, one accumulates wholesome roots without being content;
In order to cross the four streams, one always cultivates the great vehicle of Dharma well. In order to enable sentient beings to reach the other shore, one constructs bridges well.
Bodhisattvas always use a mind that is not lazy or retreating to pull sentient beings out of the mud of birth and death and bring them to a place of peace and security.
Ocean-minded One!

If bodhisattvas are able to cultivate these various aspects of practice, they will be able to perfect the practice of giving and also be able to purify the practice of upholding precepts. This is how bodhisattvas are able to skillfully polish the mind-jewel that aspires to omniscience.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
First, one should skillfully guard the body, speech, and mind, and protect the ten kinds of pure karmas;
With a compassionate mind, one observes all sentient beings, and the mind of omniscience is thus polished.
With a mind of compassion, one assists in doing what others do; with a mind of joy, one accomplishes others' teachings;
With a mind of equanimity, one does not harm any sentient beings, and the mind of omniscience is thus polished.
Because of being without flattery or deception, the mind is always upright; one stops wrongdoing and is able to cultivate beneficial matters;
Deeply cultivating the roots of goodness, the mind of omniscience is polished by this.
Because the mind is free, mindfulness and right knowledge arise; because the mind is well-tamed, the mind is at ease.
Having few desires, one is able to cultivate the causes of ascetic practices; the mind of omniscience is polished by this.
Being content, one skillfully practices the holy practices, and always respectfully venerates the teacher;
One is able to give rise to a mind of non-contempt, and far removes arrogance and wrong pride.
The mind in concentration does not give rise to conceit; because it is free from turbidity and confusion, the mind is pure.
Not relying on oneself, one is self-aware; because one does not slander others, one protects others.
Approaching the profound and firm wondrous Dharma medicine, one removes conceit and treats illnesses;
Desiring the Dharma is called seeking the Dharma; diligently seeking the Dharma is being endowed with the desire for the Dharma.
Cultivating the practice of non-disputation is called delighting in the Dharma; because one is free from non-Dharma, one is able to seek the Dharma;
Without destroying the Three Jewels, one fully believes, and the mind of omniscience is polished.
In unwholesomeness, one feels ashamed, and towards the TathÄgatas, one feels a sense of shame;
Fully endowed with shame and conscience, one guards the sense faculties, and the mind of omniscience is polished.
Clearly understanding karmic retribution and excellent deeds, one believes and understands, and the mind attached to extreme views is not clung to;
In the Dharma of dependent origination, one does not contradict, and the mind of omniscience is polished.
Well guarding one's deportment and cultivating right practice, the mind is without arrogance and always gentle;
Excitement does not arise, and one cultivates the practice of tranquility, and the mind of omniscience is polished.
Because of well abiding in wisdom, there is no praise or blame, and one calmly observes the multitude like a mountain king;
In firm vows, there is no retreating mind, and the mind of omniscience is polished.
Suffering and joy do not move the mind, which is like the earth; the mind is pure like water, washing away afflictions and troubles;
The mind is no different from fire, giving rise to no different thoughts, the mind is like the wind, moving without attachment.
The mind is like the wondrous and immaculate sky, diligently seeking to leave the home life and clarify the Buddha's eye;
The body is free, able to cultivate a tranquil mind, the mind is free, always relying on the practice of the true Dharma.
What is practiced always speaks true words, as spoken, able to practice with a clear vow;
Pure, not destroyed by defilement, without breaking or damaging, thus cultivating the practice of precepts.
Without deficiency or destruction in the precepts, harboring great fear for even minor offenses;
Protecting the precepts, not seeking rebirth in the heavens, the precepts are always pure and untainted.
Always able to draw near to good and wise advisors, all for them to clarify the mind of enlightenment;
Unimpeded bright light illuminates the world, this is due to attaining the pure eye.

And also cultivating the noble eightfold path;
Without greed, without anger, without fear, they are born; well-guarding the sense-faculties, they are free from the bonds of delusion.
Without stinginess, they are able to practice the giving of Dharma, without a miserly or protective mind;
Without hoarding wealth, they always give to others; they accomplish this bodhicitta.
Without hoping for any rewards, they always practice giving, loving speech, beneficial actions, and cooperation, in order to gather sentient beings.
Not abandoning bodhicitta, not delighting in other vehicles;
Contemplating the gateway of the TathÄgata's merits, their mind is as firm as Mount Sumeru.
The inner mind is tranquil, reflecting on one's own faults; externally, protecting others' faults, not criticizing or denigrating;
In all actions, free from flaws, fearing birth and death, not creating offenses.
Diligent in practicing good dharmas, without laziness, purifying the Buddha-land, without fatigue;
They protect the Dharma without giving rise to a mind of loss, and liberate sentient beings without backsliding.
They always diligently cultivate the great Dharma boat, and ferry across the four streams of the ocean of birth and death;
They also build bridges to connect sentient beings, and lead them to the peaceful ground of nirvana.
They pull sentient beings out of the deep mire, and bring them to a clean and fearless place;
To frightened sentient beings they give comfort and peace, and themselves crossing over, they ferry others to the other shore.
If one skillfully accomplishes this Dharma, then one is a bodhisattva's great fearlessness;
They are able to always purify the mind of enlightenment, and the defilements of afflictions cannot stain it.
Even the stainless sky can be stained, and the bird tracks in the sky can still be seen;
The afflictions do not stain the mind of enlightenment, which is by nature originally always pure.
Furthermore, SÄgaramati!
What is meant by a bodhisattva being able to withstand the crushing of the precious mind of omniscience that they have aroused?
Moreover, what is meant by the mode of crushing?
SÄgaramati!
If, within the precious mind of omniscience of this bodhisattva, there are people with faulty morality who are disagreeable,
or various mÄras or the retinue of mÄras, or those empowered by the power of mÄras, or sages in the palaces of mÄras,

at that time the bodhisattva should make their great mind of enlightenment firm and indestructible, and also

should not destroy the great compassion and diligence of liberating all beings, and should also not destroy the diligent protectionğŸ”½and upholding of the lineage of the Three Jewels so that it is not cut off or interrupted, and should also not destroy the diligent practice

and accumulation of all roots of goodness within the teachings of the buddhas, and should also not destroy the accumulation of merit andğŸ”½cultivation of practices in order to perfect the major and minor marks,
They also do not destroy their vigor in order to purify the Buddha land.ğŸ”½They also do not destroy their disregard for life in order to protect the true Dharma.
They also do not destroy their detachment from their own happiness in order to universally liberate all sentient beings.

If bodhisattvas can be thus complete in the profound mind and give rise to such an intention, they will then be able to endure the anger, beating, scolding, ridicule, and slander of those sentient beings.

Or if they are crushed by all sentient beings, they will also be able to bear it, because bodhisattvas universally save all sentient beings without fatigue, indolence, regression, or submergence, increasing their strength, courageously giving rise to vigor, enduring hardship and suffering, and embracing them with their minds.
If others come and deliberately give rise to anger, at that time the bodhisattvas do not respond with anger.
When others come to beat, strike, or destroy them, the bodhisattvas at that time do not respond in kind, but think like this:
'I should now don the armor of patience of the Great Vehicle.
Why is this?

Because this Dharma of the Great Vehicle is in extreme opposition to the world.ğŸ”½The beings of the world go along with the flow of birth and death, but the Dharma of my Great Vehicle goes against the flow of birth and death.
The beings of the world oppose each other, but the Dharma of my Great Vehicle causes beings to end their opposition.
The beings of the world are rampant with anger, but the power of patience in the Dharma of my Great Vehicle is strong.
The beings of the world deceive each other, but the Dharma of my Great Vehicle causes beings to perfect their wisdom.

Moreover, in the world, there may be sentient beings who go around in the ten directions, holding weapons and following the bodhisattva, in all places, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, if there is a person who gives rise to the mind of great enlightenment, or cultivates the mind of giving, or cultivates the mind of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, up to or hears of the arising of a single wholesome mind, I will go to those places and cut up their bodies, cutting off the limbs like jujube leaves.
Even if the bodhisattva encounters such things, he can endure them all.
Moreover, if all sentient beings in the world give rise to anger and skillfully speak evil words to scold, insult, and slander,
at that time, the bodhisattva does not give rise to even the slightest agitated mind towards those sentient beings.
Why is it so?

Now, in this body of mine, throughout immeasurable and countless lifetimes in the past, I have gone through all destinies and done everything, either in the hells, or in the realms of hungry ghosts, animals, and so forth, up to now in the human realm. Indulging in food, drink, and sensual pleasures, listening to and accepting what is contrary to the Dharma, pursuing with difficulty, and sustaining myself with wrong livelihood, I have been oppressed in many ways, and there is no benefit at all to my own life.

Although I have done many things, I have been unable to benefit myself or others. Therefore, from now until the end of my lives in saá¹ƒsÄra, even if all beings were to cut up and dismember my body, I would rather endure all the suffering than give up the mind of omniscience, and I would also not abandon all beings, nor would I abandon the desire for wholesome dharmas.
Why is it so?
Now, the many kinds of afflictions and severe injuries to my body, compared to the suffering experienced in hell, are not even a hundredth, a thousandth, or even an upaniá¹£ad fraction of it.
Therefore, I will never abandon the Buddha's teachings, nor will I abandon the great compassion that is the basis for liberating sentient beings.
Why is this?
As the Buddha has said, all wholesome dharmas have many obstacles. Sentient beings in the world often support unwholesome dharmas, and few support wholesome dharmas.
Therefore, I will now cultivate and practice with diligent effort in wholesome dharmas, not supporting unwholesome dharmas.
Thus, I will be able to endure all the anger and other afflictions of those sentient beings.
If sentient beings give rise to various things, I will immediately apply the corresponding antidotes.
If there are sentient beings who give rise to anger towards me and add resentment, I will then give them the Dharma of enduring humiliation.
Because I have already given them the Dharma of enduring humiliation, and because the power of endurance is manifest, I would rather give up my life than ever give rise to anger towards them.
Therefore, if a bodhisattva cultivates in this way, it will not be difficult to attain the fruit of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Moreover, when anger arises due to causes and conditions, a bodhisattva should think, I will give rise to the Dharma of severing anger.
What is the Dharma of severing?
It means if one delights in the body, is attached to the body, or grasps at the body, one should abandon all such dharmas. Because one is able to abandon the body in this way, anger does not arise.
SÄgaramati!

If a bodhisattva is able to contemplate and diligently practice such dharmas, then he will be able to endure being crushed by all sentient beings, and the mind of omniscience will not be destroyed or lost.
